Award.AwardTitle: Numerical Methods and Analysis for Induced-Charge Electrokinetic Flow with Deformable Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is an investigation of fundamental problems from fluid dynamics that arise in biology and microtechnology. Its focus is on the development of new mathematical models and efficient numerical methods to study the manipulation by electric fields of the shape and position of cells, vesicles, and drops in electrolytic fluids. These so-called 'electrokinetic techniques' are among the most common methods for manipulating particles and fluids in micro-scale devices and biological applications. For example, electric fields are applied to induce shape changes in cells and vesicles, and this is used to infer membrane properties. Electric fields are also used to form transient pores in membranes, which is an important technique to load cells with molecules for drug delivery or gene therapy. Impacts of the proposed research include the development of new mathematical models and numerical methods that will be of benefit to scientists and engineers studying electrokinetic phenomena in biology and engineering. An additional impact of this project will be the education and involvement of graduate students. The interdisciplinary training they receive will be valuable preparation for a range of careers in mathematics and science.

During the interfacial flow of an ionic fluid that is driven by an electric field, a screening cloud of ions develops at the interface and forms an electrochemical double layer or 'Debye layer'. The electric field both acts on the ion cloud it induces and drives both it and the surrounding fluid into motion. This is known as 'induced-charge electrokinetic flow', and it is an important phenomenon in applications. We address a significant difficulty in the numerical computation of such flows in the practically important limit of thin double layers, by developing a fast and accurate hybrid or multiscale numerical method that incorporates an asymptotic analysis of the layer's dynamics into a novel boundary integral formulation of the interfacial free boundary problem. A central theme of the current project is the development of a hybrid method for electrokinetic flow about a membrane. The algorithm will incorporate an analysis of the high-wavenumber or small-scale component of the elastic and electrostatic stresses on a membrane into a nonstiff method that is capable of handling the multiple time and space scales inherent in the problem. The method will be used to study canonical problems in the electrodeformation of drops, vesicles, and cells, and to examine vesicle manufacture by electroformation and coalescence by electrofusion. The numerical investigations will be complemented by analytical studies that will be used to justify existing reduced or 'lumped parameter' models for electrohydrodynamic flow, and to derive new models. The investigators also propose to develop a hybrid method for problems with ionic surfactant, which combines features of both electrokinetic flow and soluble surfactant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award supported research on fundamental problems from fluid dynamics that arise in biology and microtechnology.   The focus of the supported research was on (i) the development of new mathematical models and efficient numerical methods to study the manipulation by electric fields of the shape and position of cells, vesicles, and drops in electrolytic fluids, (ii) the development of accurate and efficient numerical methods for the computation of interfacial flow with surfactant, and (iii) rigorous analysis of mathematical models of interfacial flow, and numerical analysis of algorithms to solve these models.  This work has substantial relevance in technological applications.  For example, electric fields are applied to induce shape changes in cells and vesicles, and this is used to infer membrane properties. Electric fields are also used to form transient pores in membranes, which is an important technique to load cells with molecules for drug delivery or gene therapy.   Similarly, surfactant effects are increasingly important in microscale flow applications and the manipulation of microfluidic drops and bubbles. Surfactant are also currently in commercial use as detergents, emulsifiers, or foaming and wetting agents in a range of industrial and domestic applications. 

Broader impacts of the proposed research include the development of new mathematical models and numerical methods that will be of benefit to scientists and engineers studying electrokinetic  phenomena and surfactant effects in biology and engineering. An additional impact of this project was the education and involvement of graduate students, including underrepresented minorities. The interdisciplinary training they received will be valuable preparation for a range of careers in mathematics and science.

Problems of electrokinetic flow and interfacial flow with surfactant share the difficulty that in a representative physical limit, a narrow transition layer develops adjacent to the interface, in which either the ion or surfactant concentration gradients are large. This severely inhibits the application of standard numerical methods, which are unable to resolve the transition layer dynamics in a way that is both accurate and efficient.  A central theme of the investigators work is the development of hybrid or multiscale numerical methods to resolve the transition layer. These methods utilize a separate analytical reduction of the dynamics in the transition layer, which is then coupled to accurate boundary integral simulation of the interfacial flow problem in the `outer' region, away from the layer.   The methods have been used by the investigators to study canonical problems on the deformation and break up of electrolyte drops in an imposed electric field.  They have also been used to investigate the effect of surfactant on the behavior of drops and fluid interfaces in microfluidic flow-focussing devices. Such devices are used to produce monodisperse or uniform arrays of microfluidic drops for technological applications, including drug delivery.

The investigators also worked on the development of fast and accurate boundary integral numerical methods for general interface problems involving multiply-connected domains, i.e., domains with multiple interface components.  Boundary integral methods are widely regarded to be among the most accurate numerical methods for interface problems, but are known to lose accuracy when separate boundary components are close or nearly touching.   Problems involving multiply-connected domains are important in applications including, for example, electromagnetic scattering in media with multiple inclusions and particle-laden fluid flows.  The investigators have  developed new boundary integral methods that are fast, accurate, and retain high accuracy even when two boundary components are arbitrarily close.  The methods developed by the investigators will be useful to scientists and engineers studying electromagnetic wave propagation and fluid flow in multiply-connected domains.


Last Modified: 05/31/2019
Modified by: Michael Siegel
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF award supported research on fundamental problems from fluid dynamics that arise in biology and microtechnology. The focus of the supported research was on (i) the development of new mathematical models and efficient numerical methods to study the manipulation by electric fields of the shape and position of cells, vesicles, and drops in electrolytic fluids, (ii) the development of accurate and efficient numerical methods for the computation of interfacial flow with surfactant, and (iii) rigorous analysis of mathematical models of interfacial flow, and numerical analysis of algorithms to solve these models. This work has substantial relevance in technological applications. For example, electric fields are applied to induce shape changes in cells and vesicles, and this is used to infer membrane properties. Electric fields are also used to form transient pores in membranes, which is an important technique to load cells with molecules for drug delivery or gene therapy. Similarly, surfactant effects are increasingly important in microscale flow applications and the manipulation of microfluidic drops and bubbles. Surfactant are also currently in commercial use as detergents, emulsifiers, or foaming and wetting agents in a range of industrial and domestic applications. Broader impacts of the proposed research include the development of new mathematical models and numerical methods that will be of benefit to scientists and engineers studying electrokinetic phenomena and surfactant effects in biology and engineering. An additional impact of this project was the education and involvement of graduate students, including underrepresented minorities. The interdisciplinary training they received will be valuable preparation for a range of careers in mathematics and science. Problems of electrokinetic flow and interfacial flow with surfactant share the difficulty that in a representative physical limit, a narrow transition layer develops adjacent to the interface, in which either the ion or surfactant concentration gradients are large. This severely inhibits the application of standard numerical methods, which are unable to resolve the transition layer dynamics in a way that is both accurate and efficient. A central theme of the investigators work is the development of hybrid or multiscale numerical methods to resolve the transition layer. These methods utilize a separate analytical reduction of the dynamics in the transition layer, which is then coupled to accurate boundary integral simulation of the interfacial flow problem in the `outer' region, away from the layer. The methods have been used by the investigators to study canonical problems on the deformation and break up of electrolyte drops in an imposed electric field. They have also been used to investigate the effect of surfactant on the behavior of drops and fluid interfaces in microfluidic flow-focussing devices. Such devices are used to produce monodisperse or uniform arrays of microfluidic drops for technological applications, including drug delivery. The investigators also worked on the development of fast and accurate boundary integral numerical methods for general interface problems involving multiply-connected domains, i.e., domains with multiple interface components. Boundary integral methods are widely regarded to be among the most accurate numerical methods for interface problems, but are known to lose accuracy when separate boundary components are close or nearly touching. Problems involving multiply-connected domains are important in applications including, for example, electromagnetic scattering in media with multiple inclusions and particle-laden fluid flows. The investigators have developed new boundary integral methods that are fast, accurate, and retain high accuracy even when two boundary components are arbitrarily close. The methods developed by the investigators will be useful to scientists and engineers studying electromagnetic wave propagation and fluid flow in multiply-connected domains.
